comments.author: dakotagau

comments.text:
+Goran Qader No, it's not. There is genetic variation between pretty much 
every two individuals of the same species, the obvious exception being 
monozygotic twins. Especially there is systematic genetic variation between 
males and females of every species. Does that mean males and females belong 
to different races? Of course not.
comments.author: Podimann

comments.text: Race is variation, simple as that
comments.author: Jeremiah Fink

comments.text:
+Lkonae Race has already been thrown out as a taxonomic group at least in 
regards to humans.  Humans are still suffering from a genetic bottleneck 
that reduced the population to a few thousand.  If humans were to be 
classified by race there would be thousands of potential genetic races with 
fluid overlap between all of them.  The only way to tell what race a 
particular human is would be a genetic test since like I said before you 
are all practically identical.  It would be like classifying dalmatians by 
how many spots they have.
comments.author: Pink Program

comments.text:
+Pink Program As I've said before, "more variation between than within" is 
not meaningful in this context.  Simply saying it makes you look biased, or 
even stupid.  

Since you brought up dogs, I'll bring up that there is more genetic 
variation between than within as well.  "Dogs that are more dissimilar to 
each other than any two humans can be in the same pedigree as a breed."  I 
doubt that, but it would not surprise me, but again meaningless.  

"Humans are practically identical by comparison."
Outright false.  If my memory serves of a particular study, the genetic 
variation (I believe it was SNPs but I can't recall) between dog breeds was 
~27%, compared to human populations at ~17%.  Yes, there is less variation 
among human populations, but there is enough to separate the groups (we 
separate groups with MUCH less variability).  The only consistent arguments 
here are that we throw out the current taxonomic system, or we include the 
variability in human populations in it also.
comments.author: Lkonae

comments.text:
+Lkonae There is more variation between humans in a race than there is 
between races.  There are only a handful of inherited mutations that are 
unique and humans interbreed so ubiquitously between populations that you 
would have to do a genetic test to determine it.  Dogs that are more 
dissimilar to each other than any two humans can be in the same pedigree as 
a breed.  Humans are practically identical by comparison.
comments.author: Pink Program

comments.text:
+Pink Program There isn't enough regional genetic variation to warrant 
classification?  Oh yes there is.  If your argument was true, then doctors 
wouldn't be worrying about the genetic variation in humans in treating for 
different diseases.
comments.author: Lkonae

comments.text:
+brandon idgaf there are no breeds of humans.  Humans are human.  There 
aren't enough differences between regional variations to warrant 
classification.
comments.author: Pink Program

comments.text:
+Podimann
you mean breeds. race is human race not black or whtie those are different 
breeds of human not different races.
comments.author: brandon idgaf

comments.text:
oh yeah, i'm not an natural english speaker...I meant breed, race is indeed

comments.author: José Herrero

comments.text: Race is an idea that "racist" came up with.....
comments.author: JackDaScarecrow

comments.text:
+Good Pie Tutorials genetically humans are practically identical.  I have 
trouble telling one human from another sometimes ^_^ Dogs have different 
breeds and if you remove the ring species links between some breeds you 
would cause a speciation event.  Technically all dogs can be considered 
wolves though as long as there is an unbroken chain of ring breeds linking 
them to ancestral stock.  If only great danes and chihuahuas  survived a 
canine blight they would be separated by enough genetic drift and 
anatomical dissimilarity to speciate.  Any two humans of appropriate gender 
and sexuality can mate regardless of "race" so the distinction is 
meaningless from a biological standpoint.
comments.author: Pink Program

comments.text:

we'd use the word "species" I can't explain this feeling of anger for how

comments.author: Lkonae

comments.text:
+Lkonae The concept of species (ability to interbreed and produce fertile 
offspring) is WAY less arbitrary than the concept of races.
comments.author: Cr0uch1ng71g3r

comments.text:
+Xenos369 "Genetically Race is an arbitrary term, you can have more 
differences within a race than between races."  This also goes for dog 
breeds.
That is a misleading argument.  There are more differences in heights 
within the male sex, than there is between the female and male sex.  That 
doesn't mean that there is no meaningful variation.  

The entire species concept is arbitrary, yet we still use it because it is 
effective.  
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genealogical_DNA_test#mediaviewer/File:European_genetic_structure_(based_on_SNPs)_PC_analysis.png
comments.author: Lkonae

top_comment.text:
They are really not that cute. And if you ever felt the fur its pretty 
gross. People are stupid to believe these animals would make good 
pets. People who believe they can domesticate wild animals should be caged.﻿
top_comment.author: watwud Scooby Doo

comments.text:
+watwud Scooby Doo Getting mauled by a large animal doesn't mean that it 
wasn't tamed. They don't always mean to do harm. Domestic cats sometimes 
bite and get playful. That doesn't mean that they are trying to maul you, 
but If you scale that up to a larger animal, a human could get hurt, even 
if the animal didn't really mean to.

And just because something doesn't work every time, that does not mean that 
it can't be done. That's a REALLY silly thing to say.

A non-domesticated ('wild') animal can be tamed, if they are raised from 
birth, but the species and individual temperament really do make a big 
difference. 

Have you ever heard of Christian the lion? He never hurt a human after 
being raised by humans. He was a pet in the city for years and was very dog 
like. He could have killed people at any time if he had wanted to. But he 
didn't. Therefore he really WAS tamed. Sure, this may be just ONE example, 
but it PROVES that it CAN be done.
comments.author: Alexander B

comments.text:
+watwud Scooby Doo While I agree that taking in (read: capturing) exotic 
animals for human amusement is stupid and often dangerous, I must disagree 
with your statements on domestication.

First off, domestication doesn't happen over night, it happens over 
generations; depending on how long it takes to breed the next generation, 
it could take several hundred years to even breed for one trait.

Yes, we can just pull animals from the wild and domesticate them, it just 
takes time. Remember that experiment with the foxes? The critters still 
bury raw meat in your furniture, but they have been bred to depend on 
humans and are relatively safe to own.

However, domestication doesn't take long to undo. Pigs, which were only 
recently domesticated (in the grand scheme of things, anyway) will become 
feral and revert to a completely wild state within the escapees lifetime; 
that's one of the main reasons the Americas have such a horrible wild pig 
problem: a couple pigs get free, aren't recovered, and proceed to make a 
whole new population, with all of the members being completely wild animals.
Even dogs and cats will become wild after a enough generations, but they've 
been domesticated long enough that the offspring of a feral cat or dog 
(even a couple of generations along) can still be raised to live 
comfortably with humans (I know this because my cat was feral born).
comments.author: ssholum

comments.text:
+watwud Scooby Doo No, I read that. It's still pretty fucking stupid and 
ignorant that you would say that.
comments.author: Templarfreak

comments.text:

 Pretty stupid to make statements about another persons intelligence

comments.author: watwud Scooby Doo

comments.text:
+Alexander B
No you can't. Just look up how many people were mauled by their pet tigers, 
lions, chimps, and many other exotic animals that they had since they were 
babies. After a certain age natural instinct takes over. And there is a 
huge difference between the animals putting up with people vs. being 
comfortable with people. Being around people causes stress for wild 
animals, making them more likely to interpret wrong move by their owners as 
a threat. Please no one try and take a baby animal from the wild and try to 
raise it, just get a dog.
comments.author: watwud Scooby Doo

comments.text:
Pretty sure you CAN domesticate wild animals. If you are talking about 
taming (making an individual comfortable and sociable with humans), that is 
also possible, if they are raised from infancy.
comments.author: Alexander B

comments.text:
Excuse me, but weren't Cows, Sheep, and Chicken WILD animals at one point? 
Dogs? Cats? And other currently domesticated animals? Pretty fucking stupid 
to say that. All domesticated animals today were once wild.
comments.author: Templarfreak

comments.text:
+OlCapitain
So we are saying the same thing. You mentioned how these scavenger wolves 
became tamer and would run away less as they fed off human handouts. I am 
just referring to them as a halfway point between wolves and dogs. I never 
said the dogs we have today bred themselves, I was pointing out the fact 
that these scavenger wolves separated themselves naturally from other 
wolves prior to selective breeding. Both cats and dogs we have today are 
the result of human selection, they started out though as wild animals who 
developed a dependency to humans first.

EDIT:  Back on topic of my original message: It's this dependency, or 
really it's more of a mutualistic relationship, that made 
domestication successful for animals like dogs, cats, and most livestock. 
There is no such relationship between humans and sloths. Most of these 
people who keep exotic animals don't seem to think about the mental health 
of the animals. They most likely don't care about the animals health 
however, it's just so they can show off to their friends.
comments.author: watwud Scooby Doo

comments.text:
+watwud Scooby Doo Wolves were domesticated by humans 14,000 years ago 
through selective breeding. They were not scavengers that evolved into 
loving dogs. They were wolves, who were bred to be un-aggressive so that 
humans could use them to increase their hunting abilities. Wolves 
themselves are not too terribly far from domestication themselves, they are 
naturally social animals and as long as you fall into their social rank, 
they do not discriminate between species. Humans used that to their 
advantage to domesticate them. Now, dogs being scavengers at first 
definitely led to their flight distance being drastically lower than 
normal, which led to them being domesticated easier. However, they didn't 
breed themselves. Cats domesticated themselves. Idc about the whole 
domestication is right or wrong debate, I am just fixing your incorrect 
statements.

http://www.livescience.com/8405-dogs-dogs.html
comments.author: OlCapitain

comments.text: Truth
comments.author: Pyro Max

comments.text:
+Pink Program
I don't think you fully understand domestication. When humans directly 
tried  to take animals they often failed like with Cheetahs and different 
types of deer. Dogs and cats, our greatest success story evolved for 
thousands of years in an halfway point where they lived with humans but 
were not subject to selective breeding. Dogs were scavengers off human 
settlement, and humans allowed it, and because of this they changed over 
time from wolves naturally. There is no evidence to suggest a person went 
out and collected a wild wolf to domesticate because that would be stupid.
And no, more effort should be made to protect the rainforests where they 
live. Domestication would solve nothing, because once humans die out, any 
animals that depends on them would die as well.
comments.author: watwud Scooby Doo

domesticated?  With habitat destruction that is probably the only way

^_^

comments.text: BEGIN
comments.author: RealLifeLab

captions.text:
There are two-toed sloths and three-toed sloths,
but other than their toes -- what's the difference?!

Hello friends, I'm Trace thanks for tuning
in to DNews! As you're likely aware, it's

SLOTH WEEK! Obviously, we're all aware sloths
are cute, slow-moving, and extremely photogenic

-- but let's drill down a little further into
these South American darlings. Why do some

sloths have two toes and some have three?
Because evolution.

First, both two-toed and three-toed sloths
have three ACTUAL toes. Yes, two-toed sloths

have three TOES, but only two FINGERS. 35
to 40 million years ago, the 2-toed and 3-toed

sloth were one species, Tara talked about
that in a different video about ancient sloth

ancestors -- go watch if you missed it -- but
at some point they mutated into these two

distinct groups. The 3-toed megatherium -- or
great beast, which was the size of an elephant
and the 2-toed megalonyx -- or great claw.

As they evolved the sloths shrank in size
and spread themselves through North and South

America -- probably to conserve energy, because
leaves aren't THAT nutritious. Though it could

also be because movement attracts predators.
23-percent of the diet of Harpy Eagles is

made up of two-toed sloths, and only 8.4-percent
by the three-toed ones. I think you can guess

who moves more. Two-toed sloths may move for
several hours throughout the day, while some

species of the three-toed sloth won't move
at all.

In case you ever run into a sloth, the two-toed
guy are larger, faster, nocturnal, and can

rotate their head 90 degrees [[pause]] the
three-toed ones are slower and more docile,

and can rotate their head 270 degrees and
can be either nocturnal or diurnal. Get all

that? Great. More importantly for you on the
internet. The three-toed are more often the

ones you see taken as pets, BECAUSE they're
cute, they don't bite and, like I said, they

tend to be more docile. That doesn't help
with their natural existence however, because
people keep TAKING THEM HOME.

There are four species of the three-toed sloth:
The Maned, Pale-Throated, Brown-Throated and

Pygmy. The three-toed sloths have a blunter
muzzle, and simpler, peg-like teeth. The cutest

of those is definitely the pygmy. As it's
name suggests, it's real tiny. It separated

from the other three species almost 9,000
years ago and lives solely on Isla Escudo

de Veraguas off the coast of Panama. Because
it only lives in that ONE PLACE, it's definitely
endangered.

The two-toed sloth is ALSO really cute, I
am sure you can see a theme here... But because

it has a more defensive temperament it will
be to defend itself. There are only TWO species

of two-toed sloth: The Linnaeus's and Hoffman's.
The Linnaeus' sloth has a HUGE land area and

super a strong population because it's got
great camouflage and is solitary, but the

Hoffmans... is a victim of it's own cuteness.
It's population is strong as well, but the

Hoffmans tend to venture onto farmland where
they can be killed. They're also hunted and

captured for the exotic pet trade, again,
because cuteness.

Another big difference between the two, is
the three-toed sloth, like humans, has a sex

ratio at birth of about 1-to-1 female-to-male.
But that two-toed devil has 11-to-1! Eleven

females for every male. When you spot a two-sloth
in the wild, look for others, because the

females form small groups, and the males are
solitary. In the end, whether it be two or

three toes -- the sloths are fascinating natives
to the Americas with a rich history and pretty
complicated family life.

Which is your favorite, the two or three toed
sloth?

Tell us in the comments below! And in case
you didn't hear before: it's Sloth Week! Check

out all the awesome sloth videos on our sister
network: Animalist. You can find more sloths

by going to YouTube.com/Animalist or by going
to SlothWeek.com. We've put links in the description

below! You can also come back to DNews for
more awesome videos everyday!
